questions.question: I ....................... Mary coming.
questions.description: When the verb see refers to perception, we do not normally use continuous forms.

questions.question: ………………….. somebody coming up the stairs?
questions.description: When the verb hear refers to perception, we do not normally use progressive forms.

questions.question: What did you put in the soup? I ………………… something funny.
questions.description: When the verb taste refers to perception, we do not normally use progressive forms.

questions.question: Suddenly I realized I ……………….. something burning.
questions.description: When the verb smell refers to perception, we do not normally use progressive forms.

questions.question: I ………………… what she wanted.
questions.description: Know is not normally used with can/could.

questions.question: I ………………… what she wanted.
questions.description: Can and could are often used with the verb guess.

questions.question: You ………………… she is British from her accent.
I ..................... what you are talking about.
She is an arrogant woman, but somehow you can’t ………………… her.
questions.description: After can’t help, we use an -ing form.

questions.question: I couldn’t ………………. what they said.
questions.description: After can’t / couldn't help, we use an ing form.

questions.question: I can’t help ...................... what she wants.
questions.description: After can’t help, we can use ‘but + infinitive without to’. This expression has the same meaning as ‘can’t help + ing form’.

questions.question: I can't help .......................... what I should do next.
questions.description: The expression 'can't help + ing' has the same meaning as the expression 'can't help but + infinitive without to'.
